Problem:
Consider an electrical circuit governed by the differential equation \\(L \\frac{dI}{dt} + RI = V(t)\\), where \\(L\\) is inductance, \\(R\\) is resistance, and \\(V(t)\\) is a time-varying voltage source. Analyze the effect of applying a linear time-invariant system transformation characterized by the impulse response function \\(h(t) = e^{-\\alpha t}\\) for \\(t \\geq 0\\), where \\(\\alpha\\) is a constant.

If the transformation \\(h(t)\\) is applied to the voltage source \\(V(t)\\) at time \\(t = 0\\), and then the circuit is allowed to evolve under \\(L \\frac{dI}{dt} + RI = V(t)\\) without further intervention, will \\(I(t)\\) at \\(t = T\\) be the same as if \\(V(t)\\) without transformation was directly applied under \\(L \\frac{dI}{dt} + RI = V(t)\\)?
Explanation: Applying \\(h(t)\\) modifies the input voltage \\(V(t)\\) to a new function, changing how the current \\(I(t)\\) evolves over time. The transformation affects the entire dynamics of the circuit by altering the input, resulting in a different current at any time \\(T\\).
